metadata.description: Chemistry questions converted to quiz JSON.

questions.question:
:
 Name the apparatus that can be used to:
 a) Measure volume of solutions more accurately than a measuring cylinder.
 b) Lower a burning piece of magnesium ribbon into a gas jar.
 c) Store and keep substances free from moisture.
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
 a) Burette – more accurate for measuring volumes because it has fine graduations and a tap for controlled delivery.
 b) Tongs / Crucible tongs – used to safely handle burning magnesium ribbon and place it into a gas jar.
 c) Desiccator – used to store substances and keep them dry by preventing moisture contact.

questions.question:
:
 A radioactive isotope decays by either emission of alpha (α) or beta (β) particles.
a) Explain why alpha particles have a higher ionising power compared to beta particles.
 b) Explain how alpha and beta particles can be distinguished in terms of their penetrating powers.
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
a) Ionising power:
Alpha particles (α) are heavier and carry a +2 charge.


They interact strongly with electrons in atoms, causing many ionisations over a short distance.


Beta particles (β) are lighter and carry a -1 charge, causing fewer ionisations.


Conclusion: α-particles have higher ionising power than β-particles.


b) Penetrating power:
α-particles: low penetrating power, stopped by paper or a few cm of air.


β-particles: moderate penetrating power, can pass through paper but stopped by thin metal like aluminium.


Observation: Using absorbers (paper and aluminium), α and β can be distinguished.

questions.question:
:
 Three bottles containing zinc nitrate, aluminium nitrate, or lead(II) nitrate have their labels missing. Describe a chemical test using aqueous sodium sulphate and aqueous ammonia to label the bottles correctly.
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
Test with sodium sulphate (Na₂SO₄):


Add aqueous sodium sulphate to small samples from each bottle.


Observation:


Lead(II) nitrate → white precipitate of PbSO₄ forms


Zinc nitrate & Aluminium nitrate → no precipitate


Conclusion: The bottle that forms a precipitate contains lead(II) nitrate.


Test with aqueous ammonia (NH₃(aq)):


Add aqueous ammonia to the remaining solutions.


Observations:


Zinc nitrate → white precipitate of Zn(OH)₂ dissolves in excess NH₃, giving a clear solution


Aluminium nitrate → white precipitate of Al(OH)₃ does not dissolve in excess NH₃


Conclusion:


Zn(NO₃)₂ → precipitate dissolves in excess NH₃


Al(NO₃)₃ → precipitate insoluble in excess NH₃


Final labeling:
Pb(NO₃)₂ → forms white precipitate with Na₂SO₄


Zn(NO₃)₂ → forms precipitate with NH₃, dissolves in excess


Al(NO₃)₃ → forms precipitate with NH₃, insoluble in excess

questions.question:
:
 For the equilibrium reaction:
2NO2(g)↔N2O4(g),ΔH=−ve2NO_2(g) \leftrightarrow N_2O_4(g), \quad \Delta H = -\text{ve}2NO2​(g)↔N2​O4​(g),ΔH=−ve
(Brown gas ↔ Yellow gas)
a) Give a reason why the enthalpy change is negative (exothermic).
 b) State and explain the observations made when the pressure in the syringe is increased.
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
a) Enthalpy change:
The reaction releases heat: forming N₂O₄ from NO₂ releases energy.


Reason: Fewer moles of gas on the product side (2 NO₂ → 1 N₂O₄) → energy released → exothermic → ΔH negative.


b) Effect of increased pressure:
Increasing pressure shifts equilibrium to the side with fewer moles (Le Chatelier’s principle).


Fewer moles = N₂O₄ (yellow) increases.


Observation: Gas color changes from brown to more yellow.

questions.question:
:
 Ammonia gas can be prepared using ammonium sulphate and sodium hydroxide.
a) Write an equation for the reaction.
 b) Draw a labeled diagram of a set-up of the apparatus that can be used to prepare and collect a sample of dry ammonia.
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
a) Chemical equation:
(NH4)2SO4(aq)+2NaOH(aq)→2NH3(g)+Na2SO4(aq)+2H2O(l)(NH_4)_2SO_4(aq) + 2NaOH(aq) \rightarrow 2NH_3(g) + Na_2SO_4(aq) + 2H_2O(l)(NH4​)2​SO4​(aq)+2NaOH(aq)→2NH3​(g)+Na2​SO4​(aq)+2H2​O(l)
b) Apparatus setup (description):
Conical flask → contains mixture of ammonium sulphate and sodium hydroxide.


Delivery tube → carries evolved NH₃ gas.


Drying tube → contains quicklime (CaO) or concentrated NaOH pellets to dry NH₃.


Gas jar → collects dry NH₃ over water or by downward displacement of air.


Notes for diagram:
Ensure flask is heated gently if solid reactants are used.


Show proper labeling: flask, delivery tube, drying tube, gas jar.

questions.question:
:
 The electrolysis of molten lead(II) bromide was carried out.
a) Write equations for the reactions at the anode and cathode.
 b) State the observations at each electrode.
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
a) Electrode reactions:
Cathode (reduction):


Pb2++2e−→Pb(l)Pb^{2+} + 2e^- \rightarrow Pb(l)Pb2++2e−→Pb(l)
Anode (oxidation):


2Br−→Br2(g)+2e−2Br^- \rightarrow Br_2(g) + 2e^-2Br−→Br2​(g)+2e−
b) Observations:
Cathode: Liquid lead metal forms.


Anode: Brown vapors of bromine evolve.

questions.question:
:
 Styrene is an important monomer. Suggest a reagent and conditions for:
a) Addition polymerization to form polystyrene.
 b) Reaction to produce styrene oxide.
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
a) Polymerization to polystyrene:
Reagent / initiator: Benzoyl peroxide or heat (radical initiator).


Condition: Heat or high pressure.


nC6H5CH=CH2→heatBenzoyl peroxide[−CH2−CH(C6H5)−]nnC_6H_5CH=CH_2 \xrightarrow[\text{heat}]{\text{Benzoyl peroxide}} [-CH_2-CH(C_6H_5)-]_nnC6​H5​CH=CH2​Benzoyl peroxideheat​[−CH2​−CH(C6​H5​)−]n​
b) Formation of styrene oxide (epoxidation):
Reagent: Peracetic acid (CH₃CO₃H) or m-CPBA (meta-chloroperbenzoic acid).


Condition: Cold, inert solvent.


C6H5CH=CH2+RCO3H→C6H5CH−CH2(epoxide)C_6H_5CH=CH_2 + RCO_3H \rightarrow C_6H_5CH-CH_2 \text{(epoxide)}C6​H5​CH=CH2​+RCO3​H→C6​H5​CH−CH2​(epoxide)

questions.question:
:
 Explain why ethanol has a higher boiling point than dimethyl ether.
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
Ethanol (CH₃CH₂OH) → can form hydrogen bonds (–OH group).


Dimethyl ether (CH₃OCH₃) → cannot form hydrogen bonds effectively, only weak dipole-dipole forces.


Hydrogen bonding is stronger → ethanol molecules are held together more strongly → higher boiling point.

questions.question:
:
 A sample of an unknown gas occupies 5.6 dm³ at 1 atm and 27°C. Calculate the number of moles of the gas.
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
Given:
V=5.6 dm³=5.6×10−3 m³V = 5.6 \text{ dm³} = 5.6 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m³}V=5.6 dm³=5.6×10−3 m³


P=1 atm=1.013×105 PaP = 1 \text{ atm} = 1.013 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa}P=1 atm=1.013×105 Pa


T=27°C=300KT = 27°C = 300 KT=27°C=300K (approx)


R=8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹R = 8.314 \text{ J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹}R=8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹


Use ideal gas equation:
PV=nRT⇒n=PVRTPV = nRT \Rightarrow n = \frac{PV}{RT}PV=nRT⇒n=RTPV​
Step-by-step:
n=1.013×105×5.6×10−38.314×300n = \frac{1.013 \times 10^5 \times 5.6 \times 10^{-3}}{8.314 \times 300}n=8.314×3001.013×105×5.6×10−3​ n=567.282494.2≈0.227 moln = \frac{567.28}{2494.2} \approx 0.227 \text{ mol}n=2494.2567.28​≈0.227 mol
Answer: n≈0.23 moln \approx 0.23 \text{ mol}n≈0.23 mol

questions.question:
:
 The rate of a reaction doubles when the concentration of reactant A is doubled, but does not change when the concentration of B is doubled. Determine the order of reaction with respect to A, B, and overall.
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
Given:
Rate doubles when [A] doubles → first order with respect to A.


Rate unchanged when [B] doubles → zero order with respect to B.


Rate law:
Rate=k[A]1[B]0=k[A]\text{Rate} = k[A]^1[B]^0 = k[A]Rate=k[A]1[B]0=k[A]
Overall order:
1+0=11 + 0 = 11+0=1
Answer:
Order w.r.t A: 1


Order w.r.t B: 0


Overall order: 1

questions.question:
:
 Hydrogen gas can be prepared by electrolysis of acidified water.
a) Explain why the water is acidified before electrolysis.
 b) Calculate the volume of hydrogen gas produced when a current of 12 A is used for 2 hours. (Faraday = 96,500 C, 1 mol gas = 24,000 cm³)
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
a) Why acidify water:
Pure water is a poor conductor of electricity.


Adding an acid (e.g., H₂SO₄) increases the ionic conductivity, allowing the current to pass.


b) Volume of H₂:
Step 1: Total charge passed
Q=I⋅t=12 A⋅2 h⋅3600 s/h=12⋅7200=86,400 CQ = I \cdot t = 12 \text{ A} \cdot 2 \text{ h} \cdot 3600 \text{ s/h} = 12 \cdot 7200 = 86,400 \text{ C}Q=I⋅t=12 A⋅2 h⋅3600 s/h=12⋅7200=86,400 C
Step 2: Moles of electrons
Moles e⁻=QF=86,40096,500≈0.895 mol e⁻\text{Moles e⁻} = \frac{Q}{F} = \frac{86,400}{96,500} \approx 0.895 \text{ mol e⁻}Moles e⁻=FQ​=96,50086,400​≈0.895 mol e⁻
Step 3: Moles of H₂ formed
2H⁺+2e−→H22\text{H⁺} + 2e⁻ \rightarrow H₂2H⁺+2e−→H2​
2 moles of electrons produce 1 mole of H₂:


nH2=0.8952≈0.4475 moln_{H₂} = \frac{0.895}{2} \approx 0.4475 \text{ mol}nH2​​=20.895​≈0.4475 mol
Step 4: Volume of H₂
V=n⋅24,000=0.4475⋅24,000≈10,740 cm³≈10.7 dm³V = n \cdot 24,000 = 0.4475 \cdot 24,000 \approx 10,740 \text{ cm³} \approx 10.7 \text{ dm³}V=n⋅24,000=0.4475⋅24,000≈10,740 cm³≈10.7 dm³
Answer: V≈10.7 dm³V \approx 10.7 \text{ dm³}V≈10.7 dm³

questions.question:
:
 Ethanol can be prepared from glucose:
C6H12O6(aq)→2C2H5OH(aq)+2CO2(g)C_6H_{12}O_6(aq) \rightarrow 2C_2H_5OH(aq) + 2CO_2(g)C6​H12​O6​(aq)→2C2​H5​OH(aq)+2CO2​(g)
a) Explain why temperatures >30 °C are not used.
 b) The concentration of ethanol is ~12%. How can it be increased?
 c) State one use of ethanol in hospitals.
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
a) Temperature limitation:
Yeast produces ethanol efficiently at ≤30 °C.


Higher temperature → yeast denatured → fermentation stops.


b) Increasing ethanol concentration:
Use fractional distillation to concentrate ethanol.


c) Use of ethanol in hospitals:
As disinfectant or antiseptic for cleaning wounds and instruments.

questions.question:
:
 Paper chromatography of a dye:
a) Why is the baseline drawn with a pencil?
 b) Why is the paper placed with baseline above solvent?
 c) Why is the beaker covered?
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
a) Pencil baseline:
Pencil does not dissolve in solvent, unlike ink, preventing interference.


b) Baseline above solvent:
Prevents the sample from dissolving directly into the solvent, allowing proper separation.


c) Covered beaker:
Maintains saturated solvent vapour, reducing evaporation and ensuring consistent movement.

questions.question:
:
 6.12 g of H₂O₂ dissolved in 100 cm³ of water decomposes:
2H2O2(aq)→2H2O(l)+O2(g)2H_2O_2(aq) \rightarrow 2H_2O(l) + O_2(g)2H2​O2​(aq)→2H2​O(l)+O2​(g)
a) Name a suitable catalyst.
 b) Calculate moles of H₂O₂.
 c) Calculate volume of O₂ produced (1 mol gas = 24,000 cm³).
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
a) Catalyst:
Manganese(IV) oxide, MnO₂.


b) Moles of H₂O₂:
Molar mass H₂O₂=2(1)+2(16)=34 g/mol\text{Molar mass H₂O₂} = 2(1) + 2(16) = 34\text{ g/mol}Molar mass H₂O₂=2(1)+2(16)=34 g/mol n=6.1234≈0.18 moln = \frac{6.12}{34} \approx 0.18 \text{ mol}n=346.12​≈0.18 mol
c) Volume of O₂ produced:
Stoichiometry: 2 mol H₂O₂ → 1 mol O₂


nO2=0.182=0.09 moln_{O₂} = \frac{0.18}{2} = 0.09 \text{ mol}nO2​​=20.18​=0.09 mol V=0.09⋅24,000≈2,160 cm³V = 0.09 \cdot 24,000 \approx 2,160 \text{ cm³}V=0.09⋅24,000≈2,160 cm³
Answer: V≈2.16 dm³V \approx 2.16 \text{ dm³}V≈2.16 dm³

questions.question:
:
 Describe how a sample of ammonium nitrate can be prepared using ammonia as the only nitrogen-containing compound.
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
Method:
Dissolve ammonia gas in water → forms ammonium hydroxide:


NH3+H2O→NH4OHNH_3 + H_2O \rightarrow NH_4OHNH3​+H2​O→NH4​OH
Add nitric acid carefully (neutralization):


NH4OH+HNO3→NH4NO3+H2ONH_4OH + HNO_3 \rightarrow NH_4NO_3 + H_2ONH4​OH+HNO3​→NH4​NO3​+H2​O
Evaporate water to crystallize ammonium nitrate.


Observations / Notes:
White crystalline solid forms.


Handle carefully, avoid heating too much (explosive when dry in bulk).

questions.question:
:
 Sodium reacts with water to produce sodium hydroxide and hydrogen gas.
a) Write a balanced chemical equation.
 b) State one safety precaution when carrying out the reaction.
 c) Explain why the reaction is more vigorous with hot water.
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
a) Balanced equation:
2Na(s)+2H2O(l)→2NaOH(aq)+H2(g)2Na(s) + 2H_2O(l) \rightarrow 2NaOH(aq) + H_2(g)2Na(s)+2H2​O(l)→2NaOH(aq)+H2​(g)
b) Safety precaution:
Conduct in small quantities and away from flammable materials.


Wear gloves and goggles.


c) Hot water effect:
Higher temperature → increased kinetic energy → faster reaction → more vigorous release of H₂.

questions.question:
:
 A student tested a solution of copper(II) sulfate with sodium hydroxide.
a) State the observation.
 b) Write a balanced equation for the reaction.
 c) Name the type of reaction.
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
a) Observation:
Blue precipitate forms.


b) Equation:
CuSO4(aq)+2NaOH(aq)→Cu(OH)2(s)+Na2SO4(aq)CuSO_4(aq) + 2NaOH(aq) \rightarrow Cu(OH)_2(s) + Na_2SO_4(aq)CuSO4​(aq)+2NaOH(aq)→Cu(OH)2​(s)+Na2​SO4​(aq)
c) Type of reaction:
Double displacement (precipitation reaction).

questions.question:
:
 Explain how you would distinguish between zinc nitrate, aluminium nitrate, and lead(II) nitrate using aqueous sodium sulfate and aqueous ammonia.
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
Step 1: Sodium sulfate test:
Add Na₂SO₄ to each solution:


Lead(II) nitrate → white precipitate of PbSO₄.


Zinc nitrate → no precipitate.


Aluminium nitrate → no precipitate.


Step 2: Aqueous ammonia test:
Add NH₃(aq):


Zinc nitrate → white precipitate Zn(OH)₂, dissolves in excess NH₃ → [Zn(NH₃)₄]²⁺ (colorless solution).


Aluminium nitrate → white precipitate Al(OH)₃, does not dissolve in excess NH₃.


Summary Table:
Salt
Na₂SO₄
NH₃(aq)
Pb(NO₃)₂
White ppt
Soluble in excess? N/A
Zn(NO₃)₂
None
White ppt → dissolves
Al(NO₃)₃
None
White ppt → insoluble

questions.question:
:
 Ethanol burns in air:
C2H5OH+3O2→2CO2+3H2OC_2H_5OH + 3O_2 \rightarrow 2CO_2 + 3H_2OC2​H5​OH+3O2​→2CO2​+3H2​O
a) State one observation during the reaction.
 b) Calculate mass of CO₂ produced from 46 g ethanol. (Molar mass C₂H₅OH = 46 g/mol, CO₂ = 44 g/mol)
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
a) Observation:
Blue flame, water vapor, and carbon dioxide formed.


b) Mass of CO₂:
Step 1: Moles of ethanol
n=4646=1 moln = \frac{46}{46} = 1 \text{ mol}n=4646​=1 mol
Step 2: Moles of CO₂ produced
C2H5OH+3O2→2CO2+3H2OC_2H_5OH + 3O_2 \rightarrow 2CO_2 + 3H_2OC2​H5​OH+3O2​→2CO2​+3H2​O
1 mol ethanol → 2 mol CO₂


nCO2=2 moln_{CO₂} = 2 \text{ mol}nCO2​​=2 mol
Step 3: Mass of CO₂
m=n⋅M=2⋅44=88 gm = n \cdot M = 2 \cdot 44 = 88 \text{ g}m=n⋅M=2⋅44=88 g
Answer: 88 g CO₂

questions.question:
:
 Ammonium chloride is heated:
a) Write a chemical equation for decomposition.
 b) State one observation.
 c) Explain how the gas evolved can be collected.
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
a) Equation:
NH4Cl(s)→ΔNH3(g)+HCl(g)NH_4Cl(s) \xrightarrow{\Delta} NH_3(g) + HCl(g)NH4​Cl(s)Δ​NH3​(g)+HCl(g)
b) Observation:
White fumes (of NH₃ and HCl mixing in air) appear.


Solid disappears gradually.


c) Gas collection:
Sublimation/Downward delivery: Ammonium chloride can be sublimed into a cold container because the gas mixture is denser than air.

questions.question:
:
 Hydrogen gas can be prepared by electrolysis of acidified water.
a) Explain why the water is acidified before electrolysis.
 b) Calculate the volume of hydrogen gas produced when a current of 12 A is used for 2 hours. (Faraday = 96,500 C, 1 mol gas = 24,000 cm³)
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
a) Reason for acidification:
Pure water is a poor conductor.


Adding an acid (HCl or H₂SO₄) provides ions (H⁺, SO₄²⁻) → increases conductivity.


b) Calculation:
Step 1: Total charge (Q)
Q=I⋅t=12 A⋅(2⋅3600 s)=12⋅7200=86,400 CQ = I \cdot t = 12 \, A \cdot (2 \cdot 3600 \, s) = 12 \cdot 7200 = 86,400 \, CQ=I⋅t=12A⋅(2⋅3600s)=12⋅7200=86,400C
Step 2: Moles of electrons
n(e−)=QF=86,40096,500≈0.895 mol e⁻n(e^-) = \frac{Q}{F} = \frac{86,400}{96,500} \approx 0.895 \, \text{mol e⁻}n(e−)=FQ​=96,50086,400​≈0.895mol e⁻
Step 3: Moles of H₂
 Reaction at cathode:
2H++2e−→H22H^+ + 2e^- \rightarrow H_22H++2e−→H2​
2 moles of electrons produce 1 mole H₂.


n(H2)=0.8952≈0.4475 moln(H_2) = \frac{0.895}{2} \approx 0.4475 \text{ mol}n(H2​)=20.895​≈0.4475 mol
Step 4: Volume of H₂
V=n⋅24,000≈0.4475⋅24,000≈10,740 cm³V = n \cdot 24,000 \approx 0.4475 \cdot 24,000 \approx 10,740 \, \text{cm³}V=n⋅24,000≈0.4475⋅24,000≈10,740cm³
Answer: 10.74 L H₂

questions.question:
:
 Ethanol can be prepared from glucose:
C6H12O6(aq)→2C2H5OH(aq)+2CO2(g)C_6H_{12}O_6(aq) \rightarrow 2C_2H_5OH(aq) + 2CO_2(g)C6​H12​O6​(aq)→2C2​H5​OH(aq)+2CO2​(g)
a) Explain why temperatures above 30 °C are not used.
 b) State how to increase ethanol concentration in the product.
 c) Give one hospital use of ethanol.
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
a) Temperature limit:
Yeast ferments glucose → produces ethanol.


T > 30 °C → enzymes denature → fermentation slows/stops.


b) Increase ethanol concentration:
Fractional distillation after fermentation.


Or remove ethanol during fermentation to prevent inhibition.


c) Hospital use:
Disinfectant / antiseptic.

questions.question:
:
 Paper chromatography procedure:
a) Give reasons for:
Drawing baseline with a pencil.


Placing baseline above solvent surface.


Covering the beaker.
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
Pencil baseline: graphite is insoluble → does not dissolve in solvent.


Baseline above solvent: prevents sample from dissolving in solvent.


Covering beaker: prevents evaporation → maintains constant solvent composition.

questions.question:
:
 6.12 g hydrogen peroxide decomposes:
2H2O2(aq)→2H2O(l)+O2(g)2H_2O_2(aq) \rightarrow 2H_2O(l) + O_2(g)2H2​O2​(aq)→2H2​O(l)+O2​(g)
a) Name a suitable catalyst.
 b) Calculate:
Moles H₂O₂


Volume of O₂ gas produced (1 mol gas = 24,000 cm³)
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
a) Catalyst:
Manganese(IV) oxide (MnO₂)


b) Calculation:
Step 1: Moles of H₂O₂
MH2O2=2(1)+2(16)=34 g/molM_{H_2O_2} = 2(1) + 2(16) = 34 \, g/molMH2​O2​​=2(1)+2(16)=34g/mol n=6.1234≈0.18 moln = \frac{6.12}{34} \approx 0.18 \text{ mol}n=346.12​≈0.18 mol
Step 2: Moles of O₂
 Reaction: 2 H₂O₂ → 1 O₂
n(O2)=0.182=0.09 moln(O_2) = \frac{0.18}{2} = 0.09 \, \text{mol}n(O2​)=20.18​=0.09mol
Step 3: Volume of O₂
V=0.09⋅24,000≈2,160 cm³V = 0.09 \cdot 24,000 \approx 2,160 \, \text{cm³}V=0.09⋅24,000≈2,160cm³
Answer: 2.16 L O₂

questions.question:
:
 Helium is used in weather balloons. A balloon is filled with 100 g of He at 25 °C, 1 atm.
a) Determine the volume at 25 °C, 1 atm.
 b) Determine the volume at 10 °C, 0.85 atm.
questions.solution:
/ Answer:
Step 1: Moles of He
n=mM=1004=25 moln = \frac{m}{M} = \frac{100}{4} = 25 \, \text{mol}n=Mm​=4100​=25mol
Step 2: Volume at 25 °C, 1 atm
V=n⋅24 dm³=25⋅24=600 dm³V = n \cdot 24 \, \text{dm³} = 25 \cdot 24 = 600 \, \text{dm³}V=n⋅24dm³=25⋅24=600dm³
Step 3: Volume at 10 °C, 0.85 atm
Use combined gas law: P1V1T1=P2V2T2\frac{P_1 V_1}{T_1} = \frac{P_2 V_2}{T_2}T1​P1​V1​​=T2​P2​V2​​


V2=V1⋅P1P2⋅T2T1V_2 = V_1 \cdot \frac{P_1}{P_2} \cdot \frac{T_2}{T_1}V2​=V1​⋅P2​P1​​⋅T1​T2​​
Convert to Kelvin:
T1=25+273=298 K,T2=10+273=283 KT_1 = 25 + 273 = 298 \, K, \quad T_2 = 10 + 273 = 283 \, KT1​=25+273=298K,T2​=10+273=283K V2=600⋅10.85⋅283298≈600⋅1.176⋅0.949≈670 dm³V_2 = 600 \cdot \frac{1}{0.85} \cdot \frac{283}{298} \approx 600 \cdot 1.176 \cdot 0.949 \approx 670 \, \text{dm³}V2​=600⋅0.851​⋅298283​≈600⋅1.176⋅0.949≈670dm³
Answer:
V₁ = 600 dm³


V₂ ≈ 670 dm³
